content:
9, 2016
												This may be the single most underrated video game of all time. In fairness, the original version (as I played it on my Xbox) was indeed a bit of a mess. I have no idea why this game was recently updated with full modern game amenities (steam cloud, achievements, controller support, workshop, etc) but it's one of the happiest gaming surprises I've ever experienced. Playing through this game again - this time with the restored content mod - was an awesome opportunity I never thought I would have.If the philosophy of Star Wars has ever interested you in a deeper way, this game was written for you. The way the story deconstructs the Force - what it means to be a Jedi, a Sith, what generalizations those titles reflect, and what meaning they contain is infinitely fascinating, and I find myself reflecting on the scenarios and characters introduced in this game more so than any other Star Wars property (and most science fiction in general).If you want to unravel the true mysteries of the Force - or just want to find out what happens after the first KotOR - this game is definitely worth your time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 26, 2014
												The first in a series of flawed diamonds by Obsidian.It was a warm summer's day when Bioware was busy working on other projects that they had started and soon discovered that they couldn't fit KoToR 2 into their projects. So they walked over to Obsidian entertainment and knocked on the door and formed an agreement to allow Obsidian to develop KoTor 2 for them. However, Bioware was impatient so they only had a year of development time to work on it. Obsidian sat down and immediatley got to work, as the studio only had around 10-15 people working in it at the time, all the time they had was invaluable. Lots of time was spent making assests that were never put into the final game, thus, time was spent. Obsidians greatest strength was in the writing department, as they did not view moral choices just as a simple "black & white" dialogue option. No, to them it was all grey, as in you could save the princess but you had to let the dragon destroy the village choices. In Obsidian's characters, everybody has a personality that expressed what kind of person every character was, just through talking to the player. Obsidian were true nobles in this field.As Obsidian got closer to the deadline, more and more assests were cut from the final game. Leaving the original vision a "Treasure in a deep sea of monsters." Many assests were cut and untested and unfiltered bugs were present due to the short QA testing period that was received. Distraught as they were at the final product, Obsidian regretted spending too much time developing certain assests of the game and too little time in other parts. With fear of negative criticism from the press, fans, and of course Bioware, Obsidian took to the internet to see what the public was saying about KoToR 2. To their surprise, the fans loved it with negative criticism going toward the number of many bugs and glitches that were present, and postive criticism going toward everything included in the writing, especially the dialogue from party members like Kreia and Atton. Given the number of people working at Obsidian at the time and the amount of time they had, Obsidian managed to turn a Hardees into a Jack-in-the-box. Kreia even went on to win "Most Original character of the year" from Gamespy that year.Obsidian learning from their first project, went on to make memorable game such as Alpha Protocol, Neverwinter Nights 2 + Expansions, Fallout: New Vegas (which suffered a similar experience), and soon to be South Park: The Stick of truth and Pillars of Eternity. If you like RPG's with great characters and grey morality, then Obsidian has it down.

content:
9, 2016
												This may be the single most underrated video game of all time. In fairness, the original version (as I played it on my Xbox) was indeed a bit of a mess. I have no idea why this game was recently updated with full modern game amenities (steam cloud, achievements, controller support, workshop, etc) but it's one of the happiest gaming surprises I've ever experienced. Playing through this game again - this time with the restored content mod - was an awesome opportunity I never thought I would have.If the philosophy of Star Wars has ever interested you in a deeper way, this game was written for you. The way the story deconstructs the Force - what it means to be a Jedi, a Sith, what generalizations those titles reflect, and what meaning they contain is infinitely fascinating, and I find myself reflecting on the scenarios and characters introduced in this game more so than any other Star Wars property (and most science fiction in general).If you want to unravel the true mysteries of the Force - or just want to find out what happens after the first KotOR - this game is definitely worth your time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II is a very special game to me. It has a well written storyline with plenty of side quests. It has really solid gameplay especially for its age. Being able to take the turn based combat into real time freely while preparing the next few actions you want to take in combat is a brilliant mechanic. The story aside from towards the end where it just felt rushed, was actually better compared to Knights of the Old Republic I. Gameplay was heavily improved over the original game and the companions you have felt just as well developed. The tag story rich is no understatement. This in my opinion is one of the best RPG's of all time. A lot of people find you towards the end of the game are a bit strong at least within my circle of friends who have played the game. Which I find in certain parts is true but Kotor II really does bring a moderate challenge in its gameplay. I felt many of the boss battles were a pretty entertaining. Towards the end i'm not ashamed to say I abused Force Lightning Storm and some kiting strategies to deal with a lot the enemies that i'd be fighting in groups of 5 or more. The game's lightside darkside system as always is just so well designed. My favorite part of my playthrough was me trying to perspective how i'd interact with these characters thrown into the scenario of the Jedi Exile and acting on my opinion and not a light side or dark side choice.The crafting system is really well done I loved the lightsaber crafting options and skill system requirements for crafting. The skill tree for combat was amazing a lot of diversity and freedom. Getting to the force skill tree it's in my opinion one of the best skill tree's i've ever had in a game really one of my favorite parts of the whole game is the amazing force abilities and the progression they make. I only wish there was more because it was so much fun achieving these force powers. Kotor II is the dream sequel to Kotor I honestly all it makes me want is for another one. We all pray for Kotor III because of how amazing these gems of the past are. There are still a few flaws obviously in the game glitches mostly. The biggest issue the game has is its age. Not because of graphics but more because of modern optimization.To start with the issues is how often it crashes. If it crashes at the loading screen for you or something i'm sorry never seen that issue happen to me once fix its resolution in its files. I found the game crashes from being full screen in very specific cutscenes often in world transitions. Hitting alt enter in the loading screen windowed modes the game. This fixed all of my crash issues i'd often just save before a cutscene since in most games they're obviously coming and alt enter if it crashed so I could enjoy my full screen glory. (When it didn't crash happened like 5 times throughout the game no mods installed)The inventory system itself is very poorly sorted wish I had a search bar to find items or certain stat types not even a big issue though. Abusable medpack tricks like activating one during your healing round inside your inventory while casting heal. Albeit I like this trick since it helped me in a situations where I failed to pay attention to gameplay and got chunked down. The AI for companions is pretty bad they like to run into fights repeatedly forcing my to loop between characters to continuously get them away from enemies as they'd run back in on 10% health and no force points. Good times with that I can say that much.Lightsaber on lightsaber combat damage is a little bit too high. For boss battles and even regular lightsaber combat I could say even having half damage on lightsaber damage. Maybe by having a special melee defense perk to reduce the damage would be nice since my Master Flurry Shreds boss HP. While bosses shred my HP way to quick kind of reducing the excitement of drawn out boss battle. This is the biggest fault of the combat system in the entire game and it's still not even that bad. I don't know if there is a mod for this but my final complaint is these older games often have no map markers which helps exploration but is more irritating when you have no idea where to go and the journal isn't helping much. I found this an occasional issue that can be extremely annoying. My last real issue besides the rushed ending is the slow start definitely wish I could skip that start.Also not enough Sith using force lightning abilities that ♥♥♥♥♥ top tier. (Fighting the Sith was really cool in all seriousness)Summing up review in a Tldr;Pro's:-Good RPG gameplay-Amazing Real time turn combat-One of the best written Star Wars stories ever made-Pretty Lightsabers-Strongly developed characters including the player character-Brilliant Force Powers-Decently Challenging-Awesome light and dark side choices-Amazing level up skill tree-Diverse gameplay options even though most of us go with jedi for the sake of our childhood-(Apathy is death)-Great Crafting systemCons:-(Forgot to add this) Getting a lightsaber takes a bit which kind of sucks but some might find this to be a good thing-Slow start (First 4 Hours)-Rushed ending (Last 2 Hours)-Inventory system is in need of a search bar you get a lot of garbage and have a lot of inventory space I think infinite-Cutscenes crash issues which for me were cured by windowed mode in certain cutscenes (Biggest issue in the whole game)-Lightsaber combat damage is really quick the damage to saber users have is too fast I personally just wanted longer fights because how epic they were.-Small abusable glitches nothing special-Not the brightest AI but not even near broken (Sorry if this isn't written that well i'm far from an English major)Overall Kotor II is the best Star Wars game I have ever played hands down and one of the best RPG games I have ever played it's one of my top 5 favorite games and if you get into it you'll understand why.9.5/10Try to get the original first if you can and playthrough it but if not this game can stand alone easily because of how good it is.

												I have heard a lot of people say that this one does not even compare to the original... I strongly disagree. So far, this one is BETTER than the original. You can either slice, bash, or you can use an explosive which really simplifies things.- There are more but I do not want to take the time to list them.I have been very impressed with this game so far and look forward to progressing through it.

												WHat can I possibly say about KOTOR that hasn't been said yet?This game and KOTOR 1 are, to me, possibly the best games in the SW-franchise. I love the setting, thousands of years before the events in the movies. They did well with the vibe and stuff. However, please keep in mind that these games are rather old. They did work well on Steam (while the version I bought at a store and installed from a DVD required a ton of fiddling until they actually worked). They are not looking great anymore, but if you are into the story, check this out... it's such a fun story with a big twist/surprise (which of course, by now, everyone knows about). It's not quite as much fun when you play through it again, even though you can go for a different class, but the whole storyline, visiting those iconic places, unravelling the secrets is a ton of fun. one of the best RPGs ever for me, and if you don't mind playing very outdated (graphically) games, and you like SW and/or RPGs, make sure to get this!

content:
y 20, 2016
												When I gave away my old PC games I kept few of them, being KOTOR 1 and 2 amongst them. I finished both once when they went out and I was thinking on playing them again but was a bit lazy about it... until recently.If you are a Star Wars fan, play KOTOR 1, then KOTOR 2... these are the games you are looking for.I'm not a hardcore gamer, nor a good reviewer, but I definitely feel like reviewing this game. I'm playing it with the Restored Content mod and I played this game first 10 years ago, so I don't really remember which parts are new.I'll start with the cons, not very important to me, and then get to the real point:- Just few choices on character aspect. - The controls are a bit weird.- Sometimes your character gets stuck.- You felt you had a lot of moving freedom back when the game came out but, for today's standards, you don't really have that freedom in terms of where to go.- Even in places supposed to be crowded, there's not many "people".- Sometimes the game becomes incredibly hard and forces you into a combat you're not ready to win, but you can't avoid and you HAVE to win... that forces you to:    a) runaway in circles while healing yourself and/or recover force power (which is boring and you feel like cheating).    b) cheat directly and avoid wasting time doing a) I've seem some reviews complaining about some of your companions being useless/weak or not interesting... that could be true, but the game allows you to show them you think that, so it's not a con to me. Plus, there are situations and dialogues that change depending on which companions you go with.For me, the rest is great... Great story, great characters, great dialogues, attention to details... I think that you can even have an idea of what happens in KOTOR 1 just asking questions (but play KOTOR 1). Oh! and lightsabers!!In my opinion you can face the game in two ways: thinking ahead what do you want to do and choose your dialogues and actions according to that, or don't think about it and just let yourself go. I strongly recommend the second option.The great writing and dialogues (and choices) allows you to do it. If you take your time to read and answer you will have a lot of information and it will help you to get into the story; once there, you will have an opinion of what happened and what to do next that will "guide" your path.This second part is not black and white and there are many options from clearly white to clearly black passing from not so clear ones. You can even be white sometimes and black others.I'm not going to make spoilers here but, although I remember very little from my first gameplay, I remember ending up halfway into the dark side using two red lighsabers. This time I'm full light side and I'm using a single blue one. I said you don't have a lot of freedom in movement, but you have that freedom on mostly everything else. You choose your weapons, your armour, Oh! and lightsabers!! You decide to help ones or others, or both, or none... You will stop many times thinking what choice do you want and measuring the consequences... (I confess I spend a lot of time pressing X just to do those lightsabers movement).My final thought is... KOTOR 3, please! How cool would it be a similar game with the roaming freedom of GTA or Elder Scrolls?And works great in Linux!!!Final words: get this game. 9/10

content:
y 25, 2016
												Well, I just powered through my first playthrough, after putting it off for quite a long time. I completed KOTOR 1 a long time ago, and to the day it is a dearly beloved game to me.Some general pros and cons:Pros:-Turn-based gameplay with an active pause system (very handy)-Lots of cool Star Wars lore (and if you don't like that, you can skip through almost all of it)-More weapons/armor than the first game-A wide variety of sidequests-Karmic system: Be a nice guy or a scary madman (Darkside and lightside, baby)Cons:- Not a specific spoiler, but you choose if you want to see it: it will affect your attitude towards the rest of the game.  The ending. WTF?! So so so so many loose ends... -A decent number of weird bugs. However, quite a few can be corrected by workshop content-Space suit animation doe-It's not the prettiest game out there, but it'll do-Balacing issues, in turns of battle gameplay. It seems to roller coaster throughout the gameI can't say I loved this game quite as much as the first KOTOR. I really wanted to like it as much as the first, but it fell short. I would recommend checking out the restored content mods in the workshop to make the game better overall, I wasn't aware that they existed until after I finished my playthrough, so before playing I would definitely install that.I would give it a 8/10 overall. I want to be more critical, but I can't without going in-depth about the game's content (I don't like to spoil).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
  Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic: The Sith Lords  Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords is one of my all time favourite games to date. Whilst it was rushed slightly into production due to tight time constraints, the Restored Content Mod is currently available for all on the Steam Workshop if the player desires to play through the game including cut content, for a more full experience.I also highly reccommend playing through the first game beforehand, as there are several links to that game, however it is not vital to understand the story. Basic Plot The start of this sequel is quite similar to that of the previous game, however you play as a new character- the Exile. You a adrift in space in the Ebon Hawk, unconcious, unaware of what has happened. With the help of your trusty droid, T3-M4, who you can play as in the optional prologue, you dock at a nearby station- the Peragus Mining Facility.You awake on the station, trapped, and much like in the previous game you must escape, meeting interesting characters on your journey who all have an important role in the storyline.You escape the station, after encounters with the Sith, who you realise are hunting you as they are led to belive you are the last surviving Jedi.The next system, Telos, is where you start discovering that you are not the last of the Jedi, and that members of the Jedi Council have fled to other systems. In an attempt to start a resistance, you travel around to many planets locating and uniting the last Jedi, as you are the last hope for the Republic. Features The tale is extremely gripping and enticing, and whilst the format remains almost the same as KOTOR, there are suprises around every corner, with things not always going to plan- adding to the adventurous feel.There is little noticable graphical improvement from the last game, and so the graphics still feel slightly aged. This, however, does not create an impact on the enjoyability of the game as they stay appealing.The control given to the player is better than before, with more character influence, dialogue options, light/dark side paths, whereas there remains to be 2 optional endings.However, though, this game is buggier than it's predecessor due to the rushed release, but the game has recieved a fairly recent patch, which will solve most issues.The HUD, combat and controls remains virtually identical to KOTOR, so it stays turn-based, which may appeal to some, and full controller support has been added for the gamers that prefer them to a mouse and keyboard, or want an alternative way to play this title. Pros & Cons Pros:-Excellent story, with great adventure-EPIC finale-Brilliant atmosphere-New characters each with their own extensive background-Further control over your destiny, and other characters-As always, great replayabilityCons:-A few more game bugs, nothing major- but still annoying-Little graphical improvement Final Score -Another 10/10 - Would kill meatbags again Further Information KOTOR II should take a similar time to complete as the previous game, with plenty of sidequests.This game will always be at the top of my favourites. I have never played any games quite like the KOTOR series, set aside by their unparalleled stories.P.S. I personally reccommend installing the Sith Lords: Restored Content Mod to enjoy any lost cut content to give the game a fuller feel- and the widescreen game stretch fix from the Steam Workshop. However, I seriously reccommend avoiding installing 'M4-78' to the game, the droid planet that was cut from the game before release, as I believe it is confusing, and not enjoyable in any way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 19, 2016
												KOTOR 2 is a third person action RPG with heavy Dungeons & Dragons gameplay mechanics despite looking like an older version of Mass Effect.  It’s an overall great experience if you want to dive into the Star Wars mythology that took place long before any of the Star Wars movies. However, if you’re used to your RPGs being like Diablo or Legend of Zelda, be warned that there isn’t all that much “skill” involved with playing KOTOR 2. You need to plan and play strategically throughout the game. You do not need quick reflexes or any aiming skills. – 8/10As the title suggests, the story takes place during the age of the Old Republic, when everyone knew what Jedi / Sith were, and most of the galaxy was barely keeping from falling apart after a recent war. A number of years has passed since the events of KOTOR 1, and you play the role of “the exile,” a former Jedi who seems to have lost his/her memory and is slowly gaining back control of the force (by leveling up). The reason you were exiled by the Jedi order is slowly revealed over the length of the game, and it has to do with the fact that you fought during the war instead of staying neutral as the Jedi council commanded. Joke’s on them though since you’re now one of the last living Jedi and the council has been shattered with the masters all on the run. There is a ton of backstory that you can learn by talking to everyone in the game, but if you’re like me, you’re not playing a Star Wars game to read text, you want to kick some ♥♥♥ with a lightsaber. Unlike the first KOTOR game, your customizable character has Jedi powers right from the start of the game so there’s no reason to hold off on leveling. Yeah it can be a little counterintuitive to new players, but unlike many RPGs you don’t automatically level up when you reach the required experience amount. You actually choose when to level up (as long as you have the required exp) and you need to take some time to allocate your skill / attribute / power points that you are rewarded with each time you level. This is why in the first KOTOR, it was a good idea to hold off on leveling up until you become a Jedi a couple hours into the game (before you’re a Jedi you don’t get force power points on level up). As for combat, if you’ve played Dragon Age or Baldur’s Gate, you would be familiar with the way fights happen. The game automatically pauses when you come within range of an enemy, and you queue up a bunch of actions (attack, casting powers, etc.) and then you unpause and the fight occurs, both sides “taking turns” attacking. You can have up to 3 people in your party most of the game including your player character, so take advantage of the pause to queue up actions for all 3 members of your group. This can get tedious by the end of the game when you’re strong enough to stomp on most of your enemies, but this is why I said earlier that there really isn’t much skill involved with this game. Just make sure your characters are well equipped, and armed with decent skills / attributes and you’ll be fine. Despite the fact that half the people in the game use guns, there is no aiming required on your part, and just like most Dungeons & Dragons type games, most of the attacks in the game miss. Get used to the slow combat where +1 to attack is a bonus that you’d actually want.One of the really important aspects of KOTOR 2 is party member “influence,” which is separate from the light side / dark side alignment system. Throughout the game you can gain or lose influence with members of your team (kind of like friendship points) depending on the conversation choices you make, and your actions (killing innocent people or choosing whose side you’re on in a conflict).  When you build up enough influence with a team member you can get permanent bonuses such as +1 to certain stats or special powers. You also have the opportunity to turn a lot of your team members into Jedi, which is always nice. It’s a little weird but you can also turn a party member into a Jedi by losing enough influence, but this will turn them to the opposite alignment. For example I played dark side and kept insulting one of my team members until he became a light side Jedi, maybe just to spite me.The light/dark alignment system on the other hand mostly depends on how you act towards non-player characters (like killing innocent people or insulting everyone) and can have a significant effect on the game’s storyline. There are a few planets you visit where you basically choose who ends up ruling the world. It is possible (but difficult) to completely swing your alignment during a playthrough. For example, you can play as light side for half the game and eventually work your way to dark side by the end. The alignment doesn’t affect combat that much since you have access to almost 99% of the force powers no matter what your alignment is. Play evil to have more fun and get more money though. Pros:+Very expansive story and if you want to read through it you can spend about 40 hours in one playthrough. +If you’re a Dungeons & Dragons fan you should enjoy the game’s role playing aspect and complex character building/planning.+The game has undergone a major update years after release, adding a bunch of Steam achievements and fixing some stuff. Cons:-If you’re not into “talky” games you can get bored of the constant conversations in the game, a lot of which seems repetitive. Also, as I mentioned above you get really powerful by the end, and a bunch of ankle biter enemies can be annoying you without actually being a threat.-The game’s plot is fine up until near the end where honestly the main villain’s motivation is kind of dumb.-There are a number of really annoying bugs in the game but there are workarounds that you can find online.  You’ll want to make a lot of saves in this game because a few of the bugs can be game breaking.I played the first KOTOR game many years ago and wasn’t really planning on playing KOTOR 2 (a lot of game backlog and this game takes 30 hours to beat), but after finishing the game recently on a whim, I immediately started up a second playthrough to play as an evil character. I’m usually into action/shooter games but there’s definitely a lot of satisfaction to be had in building an awesome Jedi who can force lightning enemies into submission.

content:
13, 2016
												In general everyone seems to think KoTOR is better than TSL. I am not among the general.That said, TSL has some buggy stuff where suddenly you and all your people are Sith aligned. CTDs. The script language does not always make sense, and the paths forward are not always clear. The said, the scope here is almost as impressive as the philosophy.You are again a mysterious stranger. You don't wait as long to find out who you are. Mentored by an old Jedi, once again you assemble a team and make choices. Some of these forward your relationship to gain character backstory. Some of these increase your leanings. Again, you decide how you want to play: Kill 'em all and let the force sort them out, be at peace with anything that doesn't aggro you, or meh.The depth of the story, though, is impressive. There is betrayal, Jedi gone rogue, some dude who is literally falling apart after trying to kill his master, and a boss that consumes the force for sustenance. They all tie-in to the greater story explored in the novels of who is Revan, was he good or bad (or she, again, the canon is overthrown), and what force exists beyond what can be seen by the Jedi council that threatens all of Republic space? You can also help "rebuild" the Mandalorians, train your own Jedi/Sith team, and destroy a planet. It's really cool. Toss in the restored content and other mods (just like KoTOR), and you've got serious replayability.recommended buy, but again, wait for a sale. It happens a lot. Save them dolladolla bills.

content:
ry 3, 2016
												I just finished playing the game and it took my 47 hours to do just about everything the game had to offer. I played with the mod TSLRCM.Here are my thoughts on this game: All in all I would rate this as one of the greatest Action Roleplaying Games on PC (Fallout, Baldurs Gate 2, Mass Effect, etc.) but I have to admit this left me with somewhat mixed feelings.Game was developed really fast (less than one year!?) and well - it shows. You cannot rush a masterpiece.Let´s start with the bad stuff (Cons)* All in all game feels so unfinished and there´s so many places and parts in the game where you have to wonder "I bet this would have been great with one more year of time for developers"* There are some annoying bugs. E.g. after combat ends your characted gets stuck and even though there are tips that say you should turn off/on the V-sync they really don´t help in all cases (e.g. in my case). You can live with this bug as it is totally random and doesn´t happen all the time and when it does you just have to F4+F5 (quick save + quick load) after the battles.* Difficulty is so unbalanced and this most likely is due to lack of play testing. Some parts are almost impossible and some parts (most of the game) perhaps too easy. The difficult parts are the ones where you have to play without your main character and if you haven´t micromanaged and optimized the NPCs in your party really carefully. Also some skills are overbowered and some are underbowered. Same goes for items and weapons and well...just about everything* Ending...let´s just say the last place you go in your adventure takes you gets grindy and repetative. Not a worthy ending for otherwise solid story* Then there are small things which are kinda "90s" like the inventory managementBut even with those all flaws I highly recommend this game. Story is great, the NPCs in your party are well written and there´s lots of humour and good dialogue in the game. I would rate this as one of the best Star Wars saga games and to good thing is that this feels so fresh because this takes place soooo long before the Movies that you don´t know the story in advance.

content:
ry 9, 2016
												So I've owned KOTOR 2 for many years now. I got it for Christmas the year it came out, same as the original. Since then, I've owned 2 more copies of the game, one on the original xBox, and then this version on Steam.First off, this game is amazing. Comparing it to the original, it keeps a lot of the good, and makes most of it better. Don't come into this game expecting an amazing story based on your character, however, because rather than that, it gives you an amazing (and in my opinion, better) story based on how your character's actions affect your companions and the galaxy as a whole.While this game's combat and mechanics are basically the same as the original KOTOR, several mechanics are much deeper than before. Upgrading is greatly expanded, giving many options for creating your ultimate weapons. Creating and Breaking Down items has been added, forcing you to decide on what to sell and what to break down into components, in order to create another weapon or item. And since this game focuses on companions, an influence mechanic has been implemented into your interactions with them. Now, what you say and do can change how your companions look at you and change their light and dark side orientation.Now, for the bad. This game is packed full of amazing content, but due to some issues, the game is left… unfinished. The final few areas are lacking. The developers were rushed for the end of the game, and it feels lacking. Luckily, there is a fix for this. The Restored Content Mod is available here on Steam, and helps to fill in the gaps and slightly clear up the problems the developers left behind.As for the quality of this version, it is superior to the other two I owned. The others were riddled with bugs, and frequently crashed. This version hasn't crashed once in the hundred hours or so that I've played it. On top of that, it is extremely easy to get mods for the game, some of which are very important (such as the Restored Content Mod), for creating a better experience for your game.

content:
9, 2016
												TL;DR: Beautifully made game, deep story. Fixes below. You're all meatbags. All hail the Gizka's.Absolutely one of my most favorite games of all time (and I play many games). This game is a gem of both RPG's and the star wars universe because of the amazing depth in storytelling and the way it engages me and allows me to make my own choices, something I've found lacking in games recently. Originally I owned both KOTORs on xbox (and shamelessly logged  hundreds  of hours into each) and rebought them on steam for the third time (original disk broke) just to play it again.---What you need to know---Yes, the game is buggy. This was made for much earlier versions of windows and you're likely to suffer the odd glitch every now and then. HOWEVER there is, of course, a fix! A few of the catch-all fixes that I've used and have worked for the PC versions are as follows; The  swconfig  file which can be found in your game folder installation directory. Open this and check 1) Enable Hardware Mouse and 2) Disable Movies. You miss a little disabling movies and so you may want to go back and uncheck it and see whether it works for you. Last resort you can watch them through the main menu or through the magic of the internet. Editing the "swkotor2" configuration file, found in the same directory. Should fullscreen not work out for you as it didnt for me then paste the following line below [Graphics Options] --> AllowWindowedMode=1Then change the "Fullscreen=1" to "Fullscreen=0" and you'll be playing in windowed mode. Enabling compatability mode. Not difficult to do, which compatability you use depends on your system.The internet is your friend! By no means is this a comprehensive list, just the major ones that I've confirmed to work for myself or others.Truly this is a fantastic game and easily worth its price. Also look out for the Restored Content mod, which flushes out the story to its true potential and adds so much great stuff to the game! Now quit sitting around and buy the game already meatbags.

content:
y 13, 2016
												TL; DR: KotOR II is excellent, but unfinished. A must play for Star Wars and/or RPG fans. Play through it once without the Restored Content Mod and play through it again with the mod installed.I have owned this game for a very long time. I originally played this game countless times on a disc, so my Steam hours do not accurately reflect the time I have spent with this game. I am one of those people that say that this game is better than the original (although the original is extremely good too).Let's get this out of the way first. Knights of the Old Republic II is an unfinished game. It was rushed to release to meet a Holiday release date. As a result of this, many sections of the game were cut out entirely, including an entire planet, along with vital story dialogue with characters and an ending that actually makes some sense. I am aware that there is a mod that restores a good chunk of the cut content called The Sith Lord Restored Content Mod (which is very good by the way), but I will bring that up into more detail later.Take the Star Wars formula that you know (Jedi = Good, Sith = Bad) and completely flip it on its head. It doesn't do a complete turn around, but you start thinking of the Jedi and the Sith more in shades of grey than in one being absolutely good and the other absolutely evil. You get more of a nuanced education in the Force from one of the best Star Wars characters ever, Kreia. Let's be honest here, Kreia is absolutely the best character in this game and is probably one of the best Star Wars characters ever, yes you heard that right.In KotOR II, you play as the Jedi Exile, a former Jedi Knight that was kicked out of the order due to his/her involvement in the Mandalorian Wars. You were one of the Jedi that followed Revan and Malak off to war, and you were also the only Jedi that returned to face judgment. Ten years have passed since then and you return to find a threat facing the galaxy that hides in the shadows. What follows is a galaxy spanning quest in the same ship as the first game collecting companions to aid you in this threat while rediscovering your connection to the Force. It is one of the most unique takes on the Star Wars license.But, as was said earlier, it was rushed to meet a deadline. A lot of vital content was cut from the final release, but the files were still in the game. A team of modders took it upon themselves to restore this content (what they could, anyway), and it is a crime that Obisidian was not given enough time to finish this game properly. However, I do recommend that new players do not play through the game first with the Restored Content Mod and save it for a second playthrough. Playing through it first unfinished and then switching to the mod gives you a much better idea of exactly how much stuff was cut, and how important the cut content really is. If you are a fan of Star Wars, or of RPGs in general, then there is no question, KotOR II is a must buy.

content:
23, 2016
												ERMEGERD ITS MAH CHILDHOOD!I played this game waaay back in 2005 on the original Xbox and played it almost religiously. I knew every quest, every conversation, every inch of the Ebon Hawk. The irony is that I played this before the first game, so many of the easter eggs were lost on me.But now? I played it again and while the graphics certainly haven't aged well, the story is as good as ever. I played with the Restored Content Mod and wow! This game is more alive than ever. The heart of this game lies not with the combat, but with the conversations you have, learning about the Force and the philosophy of the Jedi and Sith. This game accomplishes with a few talks with Kreia more than what Episodes 1-3 could in their combined runtimes.If you play this game, it is a must to get the Restored Content Mod as it brings the game to its full potential. All the broken plot lines are fixed. The crew all have more flow to them. Most of the bugs are gone (I stress most).I played the game as a Jedi Master, and boy do you feel more like a Jedi than the ones you're looking for. I suspect the same could be said if you go dark side, which is what I plan to do after I finish my first playthrough. Yeah, I'm 50 hours in and still not done one playthrough. All of your crew have full storyarchs and backstories. You get to know all of them and have a hand in their future. Interestingly, I somehow managed to turn HK-47 into the pinnacle light side character despite his insistance on murdering the crew.That said, remember when I stressed that MOST of the bugs were fixed? Currently I am unable to continue as I've encountered a bug that breaks the controls. Hopefully its just a one-time thing but I lost an hour because of it. You've been warned.As for the combat, it's alright. It's not the worst thing ever, but it's nowhere near the best. Sure it looks pretty, and the combat moves are really varied, but it does feel clunky with the way it works.If you're a Star Wars fan, this game and its original are a must-own. Together they form the backbone of the lore for Star Wars. There is a reason they are held in such high regard.

content:
, 2016
												Greetings!I want to start out by stating that this game is so much different then its predecessor.This game is dark and brooding; Knights of the Old Republic was a much more friendly feeling game to me.I have played both games multime times through. My dad played these games when I was a toddler, and he introduced me to hem when I was around eight or nine. I played both games on my dad's old XBox, and I recently bought The Sith Lords on Steam. I have already logged over 40 hours on Steam and am still not satisfied.Now for my impressions-KOTOR 2 is a game that allows you to delve into the deepest mysteries of the Force. I will try not to leave any spoilers, but you have a mentor you can approach at any time and learn of the Force, and learn from her wisdom; her mistakes. I loved this element, someone to speak to on your journey, someone to learn from. Th eavailable party members in this game are extremely varied in personality and background. KOTOR 2 introduced an influence system. It was a great addition, although didnt really change your party members opinion of you. Great system, but a few flaws. The plot has a few holes, but that is a result of Obsidian cutting certain content to get the game complete on time.If you have not yet, I highly suggest getting The Sith Lords Restored Content Modification, which fills many of these holes. It added new levels, new dialogue, quest fixes, and deeper character developement. The games has a sense of moral ambiguity. You do one thing, and a party member who will react positively, and another who will react negatively. Also, the mentor(whom I referenced earlier), has a skewed sense of ethical standards. She discourages giving aid, but she dissaproves of common bullying. She is neither a Jedi nor a Sith, and she is likely the most interesting character in the game. I thouroughly enjoy this game after each playthrough; I always find something new I hadn't before.If you haven't yet, I highly suggest you play this game. I sincerely hope it lives on, along with the first one, through the fans. It is one of my favorite games, and believe me, I've played many games.Thank you"It is not the destination that matters, but it is the journey."                              -Kreia

content:

												"Perhaps you were expecting some surprise, for me to reveal a secret that had eluded you, something that would change your perspective of events, shatter you to your core. There is no great revelation, no great secret. There is only you."As this quote suggests Knights of the Old Republic II's story does not share the same exemplary twists and turns of it's predecessor, but more than makes up for it in it's beautifully written characters and dialogue. The companions, in my opinion, far exceed those in the first game and while the player character's backstory is generally less interesting than that of Revan, the decisions you are allowed to make as the Exile allow for more varied replays. Unfortunately this game is held just short of being superior to it's predecessor because of it's downright exhausting introductory area and completely lackluster ending. It is well known that Obsidian was under a franctic development cycle and was forced to cut a sizeable chunk of the game to meet Lucasart's deadlines. The Restoration mod does a good job of fixing some of the issues caused by this but in no way restores everything that could have been. Despite all of these criticisms though, I can still say with absolute certainty that KOTOR II is not only of the greatest Star Wars games ever made, but one of the most charming and intersting RPGs of all time.Overall: 9/10

												Got to play it again through the Star Wars Humble Bundle and with the Restored Content Mod (Which I highly recommend installing). The story is very exciting, expecially its message to the players on the influence of the force itself through the enigmatic character known as Kreia, who in my opininion is one of the most spectacularily written characters in a game. Also, in comparison to the previous title, the story offers the player much more food for thought, and follows a much more complex route than the traditional hero defeats villain formula that the previous title followed. In terms of characters, nothing has changed. They are all very memorable, unique, and full of life.Gameplay wise, it is an upgrade to the first with much better personalization and customization with more feats, and force powers. The game also improves upon the first with the introduction to new Jedi specializations which you may learn alongside the original three classes of Jedi.  With the amount of love it has recieved from the modding community, and with the memorable characters and companions along with their humorous dialogue, this may be the best Star Wars game to this day.10/10 would love to have another bad feeling about this again.

8, 2016
												If you loved Knights of the Old Republic and you're into philosophy, morals, and wide, somewhat cynical worldviews, you will love The Sith Lords. (However, it is almost essential that you play it with the Restored Content Mod.) Where the films and the first game treat good and evil as if they were black and white, this game paints every decision past and present as various greys. This is Star Wars Noir - difficult to digest and somewhat bitter.Like the previous game, it is slow in parts, but this is one of the deepest and profound stories I've experienced. Heck, it's even somewhat meta. The first game is bombastic and grand - quintessential Star Wars. This one is subdued and brooding and it shows in the colour palate, the music, and the mood of your companions.May the Force be with you? Must it? Is the Force even worth it if it just seems to cause suffering to ripple outwards from well-meaning Jedi?

content:
er 28, 2014
												One of my favorite RPGs and probably the best story I've experienced in the Star Wars universe aside from maybe Empire Strikes Back. This story gives you a completely fresh set of characters (aside from HK-47 from the first game but his return is most welcome) and a fresh story that isn't simply copying wholesale from the movies. The game challenges the broad themes we see in other Star Wars stories while still absolutely feeling like its a part of that setting.I don't have a lot to say about the game play. Obsidian did the best they could with what they were given. I like the way you can unlock abilities for yourself and others in your crew through repeated interactions. If you've played any old school rpgs, the gameplay should be adequate, being based on d20 rules. You at least get some choice for how you level but you always have the option to autolevel if you don't want to fool around with it. You're really here for the story anyway.  And I have to tip my hat to the makers of The Restored Content Mod which, as other reviewers note, is absolutely essential. Google it, download it. I'm on my third playthrough coming back to this game after some months and the Restored Content Mod has been updated to version 1.8.3 in the interim. With this version of the mod, the experience is very minimal on bugs. The only crashes I've had could be attributed to other improperly installed content mods. Aside from this, I recommend googling to find the widescreen solution for this game. It takes a little work sadly to get this game to support modern monitor resolutions (if your monitor is 4 by 3 aspect ratio, you should be fine but if you're using a 16 by 9 or 16 by 10 and you don't want your characters to look bloated, google the widescreen fix and then the minimap fix for the widescreen fix.) So yeah, some up front work to be done but this game is 10 bucks and IMO, even with the extra work, its going to be the best ten bucks you'll spend on an rpg outside of Fallout New Vegas.

 Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords To start off my review of this game, let me start by saying that I am a huge fan of Star Wars and have been since a very young age; for as long as I can even remember. In comparison to KOTOR I I played this game about 4 years ago for the first time, shortly after I had completed the first title in the KOTOR saga (which I highly recommend playing prior to this game) and I have to say that, as good as the first game was, this outmatched it in so many ways: The mechanics of the game, whilst similar, have a noticeable edge to them in comparison to the previous titleThe graphics, again whilst similar, are refined with more detail to characters and environment, adding a little more spice to the captivating nature of the plotThe plot is much deeper and diverse than the previous titleThere is more interaction with companions, adding a significant deal of choice to the outcome of your adventuresThe side quests have much more relevance to the story and are not simple errands, as it often felt with the previous titleThere are more abilities and skills which have a great effect on your capabilities throughout the world, and depending on your skill sets the game can be a very different experience on another playthrough. As for the game itself, I cannot recommend it highly enough. There is real value in playing the game more than once, as the plot and characters/companions met through each gender are different and both light and dark side users will have compelling choices to make in terms of core storyline as well as companion storylines.I myself have used a mod to skip the opening prologue (do not be fooled, the option to skip this in game at the very start is misleading, and I find the actual prologue VERY tedious and it takes at least 2-3 hours to get through on your first go).I would definitely say that this game is not for those who want to rush through a game for the action and adventure. This is geared for people who enjoy a rich, compelling story which has depth, malleability and maneuverability in terms of what you get out of it at the end. I got this in the Star Wars Humble Bundle, but if it goes on sale on steam for around £5/$7 I would definitely pick it up if you are a Star Wars fan and have played the prequel.

The sequel to Knights of the Old Republic (KOTOR), this game puts you back in the action as a rogue jedi trying to figure out where you belong in this universe. y 1, 2014
												I played this game when it first came out on the XBox many years ago when it first came out, and like the first game, I loved it. When this appeared during the holiday sale, I decided I ought to have it on a current device and snatched it up. The game and story are still every bit as engrossing as I remember them, but I find the lack of controller support to be super-annoying. Furthermore, perhaps it is just my laptop, but graphical issues abound. I can't Alt-Tab without the program crashing (which means that any time I adjust the volume it crashes); it also crashes frequently during cutscenes. I am sure I could rectify some of these issues with some internet research and some editing of the .ini file, but I don't think I should HAVE to do that. I sort of expect the games to, y'know... work. The game itself is to be recommended, but I really have to grit my teeth and put up with the lackluster port.

content:
er 28, 2014
												One of my favorite RPGs and probably the best story I've experienced in the Star Wars universe aside from maybe Empire Strikes Back. This story gives you a completely fresh set of characters (aside from HK-47 from the first game but his return is most welcome) and a fresh story that isn't simply copying wholesale from the movies. The game challenges the broad themes we see in other Star Wars stories while still absolutely feeling like its a part of that setting.I don't have a lot to say about the game play. Obsidian did the best they could with what they were given. I like the way you can unlock abilities for yourself and others in your crew through repeated interactions. If you've played any old school rpgs, the gameplay should be adequate, being based on d20 rules. You at least get some choice for how you level but you always have the option to autolevel if you don't want to fool around with it. You're really here for the story anyway.  And I have to tip my hat to the makers of The Restored Content Mod which, as other reviewers note, is absolutely essential. Google it, download it. I'm on my third playthrough coming back to this game after some months and the Restored Content Mod has been updated to version 1.8.3 in the interim. With this version of the mod, the experience is very minimal on bugs. The only crashes I've had could be attributed to other improperly installed content mods. Aside from this, I recommend googling to find the widescreen solution for this game. It takes a little work sadly to get this game to support modern monitor resolutions (if your monitor is 4 by 3 aspect ratio, you should be fine but if you're using a 16 by 9 or 16 by 10 and you don't want your characters to look bloated, google the widescreen fix and then the minimap fix for the widescreen fix.) So yeah, some up front work to be done but this game is 10 bucks and IMO, even with the extra work, its going to be the best ten bucks you'll spend on an rpg outside of Fallout New Vegas.

content:
, 2016
												First and foremost is the clarification: this is a very long yet well-made game that is absolutely a successor to the first Knights of the Old Republic. I have only done one playthrough and it took me more than 65 hours to complete. It has all of the features of the original game and has added many new ones that seamlessly integrate with this second entry in the series. The story is rich and in-depth and the characters are memorable for the most part but feel a little flatter in this game than they did in the first. It also cleverly uses mechanics so that you can compete missions and fights in a variety of fashions and lots of your choices have very visible effects, but not all of them. Overall, this is a good game.HOWEVER, I played the first KOTOR on my smartphone and I must say I prefer that one easily over this one, though for mostly personal reasons. The story of the first one felt tighter and more polished whereas with this game it feels like they tried to stretch it out for no good reason. I felt plagued by unnecessarily long fights as a result of too many enemies and zones that are large but I couldn't see the reason why they had to be so large. I also am a completionist so I try to do every sidequest possible and so quickly became annoyed with the constant trecking and back-tracking all over every map. There is also the fact that the characters are there but feel flatter and less developed than they did in the first game; they also don't feel like they are crucial part of stroy like they did in the first game. Finally is the fact that this story just doesn't feel as good as the one from the first KOTOR. I felt like it left too many loose ends, the plot twists fell flat, and it just plain left me feeling unsatisfied as compared to the first entry there just isn't a sense of closure.Now, a lot of this has to do with personal taste and so someone else might completely disagree. As for bugginess I didn't encounter any bugs, glitches, etc. during my playthrough.In conclusion: I would recommend the game, but I'm worried you'll feel less satisfied if you've already played the first KOTOR.

content:
6, 2016
												NOTE: This review is a redux of my original review.Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords is made by Obisidian Entertainment and serves as a sequel to Bioware's Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. I've played through this game twice. My first playthrough was on the Jedi path and without the Restored Content and M4-78 mods. Honestly, I didn't like it and I wrote a negative review on it. However, after some time had passed, I tried the game again, but I went down the path of a Dark Jedi and had the previously stated mods installed. This review is based on my second playthrough:Pros:+Slightly better graphics than KOTOR I+Story is decent and more clear thanks to the RCM and M4-78 but does have some minor issues.+Details of the environments surpasses KOTOR I+Like the idea of influence and converting your party to be a Jedi or Dark Jedi+Well designed characters, but I felt their backstories weren't as fleshed out as in KOTOR I (however there are some exceptions to this criticism)+Maintained alot of elements that made KOTOR I great (choice / morale system, path of Jedi or Sith, etc)+Mods like the Restored Content Modification and M4-78 fix most of the problems found in the "Vanilla version" of the game. (Hats off to the people who developed the mods)Cons: -The turn-based combat (like in my KOTOR I review, this is something I don't like in RPGs in general)-The ending (those of you who've played the game know what I'm talking about)-The influence and Jedi conversion can be VERY tedious as some characters aren't as easy to convert / influence-I was a bit disappointed that the story didn't really relate much to KOTOR I as I thought it would be. The story is connected to KOTOR I by characters from the previous game but kinda are like side characters and refernces to events and other characters from the previous game.Overall, (8/10) Star Wars KOTOR II: The Sith Lords is a solid game but (in my opinion) not as good as the original. However, its still worth a try if your a die hard Star Wars fan or an RPG fan. NOTE: If you want the best version of this game get: 1. The Restored Content Mod, 2. M4-78, 3. Visas HD Re-Skin from the Steam Workshop.

content:
5, 2014
												(PROTIP: If you plan to buy KOTOR 2 for PC, you should, beyond a reasonable doubt, download and install the Restored Content mod. Since Obsidian rushed KOTOR 2's release for the holiday season, they had to cut out parts of this game, most of which were pretty integral to the plot.)Synopsis: You, the player, are The Exile (canonically a woman named Meetra Surik). Like many of your fellow Jedi, you followed Revan to help the Republic during the Mandalorian Wars. Revan, who was impressed with your combat prowess, decided to appoint you as one of his top generals.The final battle of the Mandalorian Wars took place near the Sith planet of Malachor V. Since the rest of the Republic's fleet could make it to the battle in time, you decide to utilize the Republic's ultimate weapon: The Mass Shadow Generator, designed by the Zabrak technician Bao-Dur. The Mass Shadow Generator activates, pulling the planet, the Mandalorian armada and the Republic fleet into a gravity field. The death of the planet and all parties involved was so great that it gave you a Wound in The Force, severing and deafening your connection to The Force.However, unlike the rest of your Jedi colleagues, you were the only one who did not fall to the Dark Side. When the war was over, you decided to return to the Jedi Council on Coruscant to face judgement. The Council, both butt furious over your insubordination and incredulous at your voluntary return unanimously chose to banhammer you from The Order. You were then exiled to wander the outer reaches of the Galaxy. Oh, and they took your lightsaber as well.-Fast forward five years later. The war with Darth Malak and the Sith was so costly the Republic can barely defend itself. Strange, phantom-like Sith assassins have dogged the Jedi, hunting them down in an effort to completely destroy the Jedi Order. The crime syndicate known as "The Exchange" has put out a bounty for any live Jedi. Strange, durasteel droids have integrated themselves into the Republic government. Meanwhile, the Republic attempts to rebuild Telos IV, a planet bombarded to near destruction by the Sith Admiral Saul Karath. An unknown figure contacts Republic Admiral Carth Onasi, requesting that you be brought from the Outer Rim to act as a diplomat to Telos. Who made the request, and why, are a mystery to you, but other external forces have plans for you...

The game has aged quite a bit graphically.  It's also probably *not* worth a second playthrough: my playtime notwithstanding (I suspect a lot of it is while the game was running but I was doing something else), most of your enjoyment of the story will be in its twists and turns.  Choosing radically different dialogue options will affect your character build and force powers, but it probably won't make playing the same thing again much more interesting.

content:
y 20, 2014
												KOTOR 2 is one of the several tales of what could have been when it comes to video games getting rushed out by the publisher; but what we do have with the Restoration Mod is still good. KOTOR 2 is probably the most interesting Star Wars story; it takes everything about the series lore on the Force, the Jedi, and the Sith and breaks them down, satirizing the stark black and white morality that the series had fallen into because of those concepts. This idea is personified in one character and that character is probably one of the best characters in video games. KOTOR 2 also actually manages to have in-universe explanations for some of the gameplay elements and it’s really well done.KOTOR 2 is not without flaws however. I found the combat to be a horrendous slog so I actively cheated my way to get to the really good parts, the roleplaying and story. While one specific character is really interesting and likable, the rest of your party is mostly more flat and aren't as good as the party members in say Planescape or Nier. Regardless I'd say it’s still worth playing and at the very least you should check out a Let's Play because KOTOR 2 really is cool.

er 26, 2013
												Star Wars: KOTOR II TSL is a classic game. The story is good, and picks up some time after the events of the first game. When I first bought this game it had 7 CD's to install so having the digital version is convenient and more reliable too. I initially made the mistake of playing this game first so if you are purchasing this game I recommend that you go and play Star Wars: KOTOR 1 first. Fans of the SWTOR MMO should also play KOTOR 1 first because it deals with Revan and the story is more relevant to the MMO. This game puts you in the shoes of the Jedi Exile and your plot-convenient amnesia as you piece together who you are while regaining the force and making critical decisions. These decisions impact your party which is an improvement over the first game's mechanics but the story isn't as groundbreaking as the first KOTOR game. I always blamed Obsidian for rushing this game, but in reality they were the ones who were prodded along to finish the game and produced a great Star Wars classic that managed to fill the shoes of the original game. It's worth the money and time to play this game if you're a Star Wars fan, and an RPG fan. The combat is fun and the story is good. Replay value is high.

content:
3, 2014
												TL;DRA Noir setting in the Star Wars universe. Need I say more?Honestly I enjoyed this game much more than the original.With the Restored Content Mod (which is super easy to download in case anyone has trepidation over downloading something from another site to make your game better) I can honestly say this is my favorite game of all time. In my opinion the reason why this game is so amazing is because all of the party members are so interesting and so well fleshed out that the only thing I can tell you without spoiling anything is if I had to make a top ten favorite video game characters of all time list, I know at least two characters from this game would be on it. One reason why I like this game so much more than the first one is because, again, without spoiling anything, the main character of the original KOTOR doesn't feel like an actual "character" until around 80% into the game, until then you're kind of just a blank slate. In this game however, you're a broken jedi with borderline PTSD. How cool does that sound? In this game your party members evolve and change personalities depending on how much influence you have with them. Its an amazing system that can change the core ideals of party members with whom you've curryed favor, and without spoiling anything, (getting kind of hard not to spoil this fantastic game haha), can lead some of these characters to become "something greater".On top of this, It also has a fantastically ominous and foreboding atmosphere not unlike Dark Souls of all games. This is a top notch game that checks all the right boxes to create a cinematic experience like no other. It opened my eyes and got me to think in a very different way that has pretty much effected the way I play all my games with morality systems to date: some times neither good nor evil are the way to go, its best to remain gray.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 3, 2016
												Very deep and cerebral RPG. Explores the moral ramifcations of having the force in a way that no other Star Wars medium has. Worth playing for the story alone.Gameplay is enjoyable if you can really figure it out, it's based on D+D and the combat is turn based, but it still feels pretty visceral. Being able to properly level your character and knowing where to properly spend points to get the character build you want is very important and very rewarding.The recent update is great, it runs at modern resolutions excellently and the controller support is actually quite pleasant to use. It could be better though, there's no dedicated inventory, stealth or weapon switch buttons despite how important those features are and combat can be a bit finnicky, as the left and right d-pad buttons control both the usable items menu and the combat menu. It would probably benefit from a seperate, controller focused UI, but the controller support is otherwise rather good - there's nothing you can't do with the controller. Due to the nature of the game, there is no benefit to using keyboard and mouse over a controller, or vice versa. It's all personal preference, and since I've played through this game about 10 times using keyboard and mouse, I found it quite nice to be able to relax and play with controller.Performance is a bit dodgy, I'd recommend turning off Frame Buffer Effects to maintain a solid 60fps. This removes some of the effects though, like the stealth effect, so bear that in mind. I found that I got about 25-30fps with the buffer effects on and 200fps+ with them off, so it's quite a difference. This is with an I5-3570k and two GTX 780s as well, so it's a bit ridiculous that I have to turn off any effects.The game is a bit buggy, but far less buggy than it was prior to the recent update. The bugs I had before the update included suddenly being unable to move, which required quicksaving and then re-loading, and dialogue randomly skipping. The random dialogue skipping pretty much ruined the ending of the game for me, as it just skipped all the important dialogue and I didn't realise what was happening. This was prior to the update though, so I'm keen to know if that bug has been fixed. I'll update the review if I experience that bug again.So yeah, if you enjoy Star Wars, enjoy RPG games and enjoy being immersed in lore and thinking about things, this game is worth picking up. Try and play the original game first though, this game is a direct sequel to the original KoTOR.

content:
ry 24, 2015
												Reguires a lot of tampering with the game files to get it working and even then it crashes every 15 minutes. And it is fun to play in 800x600 window (messes up your desktop, by the way, each time you launch the game), with the mouse escaping every time you move it and the top of the screen not showing. Well done, game developers, well done. ("Well, it's an Obsidian game" isn't excuse enough)However, is it worth it? Hell yes. It is an enjoyable game (when it works). Until you get the ending, that is. You shove the evil space witch down the pit (Return of the Jedi, much?) and then... nothing. No ceremonies, no parties, no closure, nothing but the credit roll. Even Mass Effect 3 had better ending.Darth Nihilus (the coverboy, isn't even the main antagonist) is pretty pointless. Sure he looks badass as hell, but in the game he isn't established nearly enough until you already destroyed him alongside his flagship. Also he gives no dialogue to even introduce himself.Speaking of which, most of the character intros were a bit short as well. As in: "The duck are you? Where did you come from? Well, you might as well stay, here's a bloody lightsaber." Though I have to say I enjoyed some characters more than their Kotor counterparts, and vice versa. (Zaalbaar over Hanharr, and Atton over Carth any day)Also, was it intentional to forbid the Darth Maul -looking guy from wearing any kind of robes? Those work overalls aren't wizard at all.The game is also plagued by the problems that were in the first game also, for example the Dragon Age control scheme is back. You can't aim your blaster rifle yourself. And the messing with game files I mentioned earlier. Only here it is much more complicated.On the plus side, you could become a mercenary and sell your services to the highest bidder and it would show in the story, but there were less smuggling Gizkas and I think there wasn't any bounty hunting.Though despite all that it still was a fun ride, but I still like the first one better; the story and the characters are more fleshed out and makes you care more about them. And you can't import your save from the first game. I was a bit shocked to see Bastila again when I killed her in my playthrough.

content:
er 24, 2012
												Bioware passes the torch to Obsidian Entertainment where Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords is born (TSL). During the initial release, Obsidian faced criticism over the game's abrupt ending which was later blamed on LucasArts's unwavering timeline for a holiday release. Fortunately for fans--from fans!--there is an essential modification to download to restore most of the cut content named, The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM). The game itself features a much darker atmosphere and expands on everything that made the original game great so this sequel is a must for fans.

												I'm writing a review for this game because I wrote one for the first in the series. This game is the sequel to the amazing KOTOR I. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 24, 2015
												Reguires a lot of tampering with the game files to get it working and even then it crashes every 15 minutes. And it is fun to play in 800x600 window (messes up your desktop, by the way, each time you launch the game), with the mouse escaping every time you move it and the top of the screen not showing. Well done, game developers, well done. ("Well, it's an Obsidian game" isn't excuse enough)However, is it worth it? Hell yes. It is an enjoyable game (when it works). Until you get the ending, that is. You shove the evil space witch down the pit (Return of the Jedi, much?) and then... nothing. No ceremonies, no parties, no closure, nothing but the credit roll. Even Mass Effect 3 had better ending.Darth Nihilus (the coverboy, isn't even the main antagonist) is pretty pointless. Sure he looks badass as hell, but in the game he isn't established nearly enough until you already destroyed him alongside his flagship. Also he gives no dialogue to even introduce himself.Speaking of which, most of the character intros were a bit short as well. As in: "The duck are you? Where did you come from? Well, you might as well stay, here's a bloody lightsaber." Though I have to say I enjoyed some characters more than their Kotor counterparts, and vice versa. (Zaalbaar over Hanharr, and Atton over Carth any day)Also, was it intentional to forbid the Darth Maul -looking guy from wearing any kind of robes? Those work overalls aren't wizard at all.The game is also plagued by the problems that were in the first game also, for example the Dragon Age control scheme is back. You can't aim your blaster rifle yourself. And the messing with game files I mentioned earlier. Only here it is much more complicated.On the plus side, you could become a mercenary and sell your services to the highest bidder and it would show in the story, but there were less smuggling Gizkas and I think there wasn't any bounty hunting.Though despite all that it still was a fun ride, but I still like the first one better; the story and the characters are more fleshed out and makes you care more about them. And you can't import your save from the first game. I was a bit shocked to see Bastila again when I killed her in my playthrough.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 23, 2015
												Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic 2 takes place 5 years after the events of the first. We now play as “The Exile”, a jedi cast out of the order for going to war without the councils permission. As luck would have it he/she is one of the last jedi after the Sith's successful purge and has a huge bounty on his/her head. The situation really shows in game as a good amount of people will try to kill you or deceive you for that huge bounty. It does become a tad tiresome when the same assassin droids show up time and time again spouting the same dialogue each time.  As for the game itself it plays it very safe and only improves upon a few things while keeping everything from the original intact. It is not made by the same developers as the original. Companions are far improved in this game and now feature a influence system in which they either disprove of you or like you  depending on the actions you take.  This time around there is a much better balance between Light Side and Dark Side companions unlike the original where near everyone had a holier than thou attitude. You never trust any of them either which I found very neat as I half expected the people that have my back to turn on me any moment. Some will flat out refuse to talk to you ever again if you annoy them enough. I still would like the option to kick teammates out of my ship. Which brings me to the ship, it is the same exact ship from the first game. They reuse a lot of material from the first game including planets that are ruin down but the same exact places as the original and much smaller.They really took a huge step back when it comes to environments. Where as the first game had huge unique environments this one has small gray corridor after small gray corridor. Your choices in the last game doesn't really make a lick of difference and they even get the gender of the 1st game's protagonist wrong and they will default to being female. Not a big deal at all but slightly annoying.  This sequel is far more prone to glitches and crashes. I actually had to cheat to get past a game breaking bug.  It has this incomplete feel as if they either rushed the game out or just didn't care.  It does have a few improvements like your teammate AI is much better at following you around, a small improvement to inventory menus though they are still awful and regenerating health which is neither a good or bad feature.Gameplay is pretty much the same as the original but with a few different force powers. I don't think they reused any music and it sounds just as amazing as the first.  You now seem to level up much faster and when I was done with the tutorial I was already half the level of the lasts game's character which I had at level 20 by the end of the game. Same abilities, same skills  and same stats as the first, they didn't really do anything to enhance character building. Story is pretty cool and feels much more mysterious than the first. There is no clear good and evil side in this game which is a huge improvement from the first. You never receive a lightsaber either, you have to build it if you want one. Overall I enjoyed the story more than the originals even though I saw the ending coming from a mile away unlike the first.I mentioned the first a lot in this review but it cant be helped. This sequel is pretty much a carbon copy of the first with a new story and a few highly uninteresting new worlds. It felt like an unnecessary sequel since the last game ended so well and this  game does nothing to enhance the  last game's overall story or makes any improvements to gameplay. Though if you enjoyed the last game and wanted more then it is nearly guaranteed you will love this.  It is definitely more of the same but if that is what you want than this would be a great purchase.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2012
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic was a good roleplaying game developed by Bioware. KOTOR 2, the sequel, was developed by Obsidian. The core differences here is that Obsidian still legitimately cares about making a good stat based RPG and not a shooter with romance options. I think I'm projecting modern Bioware shortcomings here but KOTOR 2 took everything that was wrong with the original and tried very hard to fix it. The game is by no means perfect, and you WILL need to download one of the Restoration Project mods to fix bugs and add content that was cut but as a role-playing game KOTOR 2 is still absolutely great. Your choices matter, the whole game is seeing how the consequences of your choices play out. This whole game is about choice. The characters are excellent, the writing is everything you would expect of an Obsidian title. The game almost starts out as a satire of Bioware cliches but quickly becomes its own animal, allowing you to explore a deeper aspect of the morality of the Star Wars universe that a lot of games never do.While this game certainly is not perfect, I find it better than the original in nearly every way. That said, I do recommend playing the original before you ever get started on this, the original game is still a good title and deserves the respect its earned. There are better RPG's out there, but you won't find a lot of them on Steam yet. For what it is this game is great and I love playing it. 8/10 would play again.
